references: Global Test and Local Test: the global and personalized model, represented by G and P, are evaluated with global and local tests respectively. Global test means all the test data is used in the test. Local test means only the local data is used for the local test and the weight of the sum in local test is the ratio of the number of data. The results of average accuracy per client are shown in TableÂ 1. Each experiment is repeated 5 times. More details are in AppendixÂ C. For readability, we only give the error bar in the main TableÂ 1 and TableÂ 2, and keep one decimal except for the main TableÂ 1.

We test the hyper-parameter effect of Î·ğœ‚\eta and Î»ğœ†\lambda in our implementation pFedBreDns,mh. The details are in AppendixÂ C. From the results, we find that it will degrade the test accuracy if the values of Î»ğœ†\lambda or Î·ğœ‚\eta are too large or too small. The test accuracy of personalized model is more sensitive than the ones of global model. The test accuracy of personalized model is more sensitive to Î·ğœ‚\eta than to Î»ğœ†\lambda. Note that the hyper-parameters are roughly tuned, which shows the insensitivity of ğ¦ğ¡ğ¦ğ¡\mathbf{mh}, and better tuning could improve the performance in the TableÂ 1.

From easy to difficult task: from the difference between the statistics of Avg and H.Avg in TableÂ 1, it can be observed that meta-step methods perform most consistently, with all other methods dropping at least 10%. This is due to the simple and effective local loss design of MAML, with its learning-to-learning design philosophy that enables the method to be more stable in complex situationsÂ [19, 20].

Absence of BNN on hard tasks: complex BNN is not in TableÂ 1, such as LSTM in pFedBayes, because it is difficult to conduct comparative experiments by fixing elements, e.g., inferential models, tricks and optimization methods. In pFedBayes, training often crashes on hard tasks and large datasets, as mentioned inÂ [77]. Our one-step-further research shows that it may be caused by the reparameterization tricks and vanilla Gaussian sampling. If we add tricks on it, the implementation will be very different from the original pFedBayes, and it is beyond this analysis.

Based on the facts, the results in TableÂ 1 shows the instability of our personalized models. Here we propose a variant of ğ¦ğ¡ğ¦ğ¡\mathbf{mh}, shown in Eq.Â (24), trying to improve the robustness of personalized model on the original ğ¦ğ¡ğ¦ğ¡\mathbf{mh}, which use Î¦iâ†fi+Fiâ†subscriptÎ¦ğ‘–subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–subscriptğ¹ğ‘–\Phi_{i}\leftarrow f_{i}+F_{i}.
The additional experiments with more baselines are shown in TableÂ 8 with the same settings mentioned in the TableÂ 1.

references: Global Test and Local Test: the global and personalized model, represented by G and P, are evaluated with global and local tests respectively. Global test means all the test data is used in the test. Local test means only the local data is used for the local test and the weight of the sum in local test is the ratio of the number of data. The results of average accuracy per client are shown in TableÂ 1. Each experiment is repeated 5 times. More details are in AppendixÂ C. For readability, we only give the error bar in the main TableÂ 1 and TableÂ 2, and keep one decimal except for the main TableÂ 1.

We conduct ablation experiments by dropping the gradient of the Bregman-Moreau envelope, the local loss function, or both, from the personalized strategy ğ¦ğ¡ğ¦ğ¡\mathbf{mh} as shown in TableÂ 2.
The relationship among the three strategies mentioned in Eq.Â (14) is that ğ¦ğ¡ğ¦ğ¡\mathbf{mh} consists of ğ¥ğ ğ¥ğ \mathbf{lg} and ğ¦ğğ ğ¦ğğ \mathbf{meg}. Moreover, pFedMe can be regarded in our framework as the one which takes the spherical Gaussian as prior and uses vanilla prior selection strategy Î¼i=Isubscriptğœ‡ğ‘–ğ¼\mu_{i}=I without personalization. Thus, pFedMe and the three implementations of pFedBreD are compared.
The results reveal the instability of our implementation ğ¥ğ ğ¥ğ \mathbf{lg} and the introduction of ğ¦ğğ ğ¦ğğ \mathbf{meg} on difficult tasks is about the same as not introducing it. However, introducing both ğ¥ğ ğ¥ğ \mathbf{lg} and ğ¦ğğ ğ¦ğğ \mathbf{meg} (i.e., ğ¦ğ¡ğ¦ğ¡\mathbf{mh}) together shows remarkable performance. This indicates that ğ¥ğ ğ¥ğ \mathbf{lg} and ğ¦ğğ ğ¦ğğ \mathbf{meg} complement each other.
To explain these results, by observing the error bars, in most of the settings, ğ¦ğğ ğ¦ğğ \mathbf{meg} is significantly more stable compared to methods that do not use personalized priors, while ğ¥ğ ğ¥ğ \mathbf{lg} is relatively less stable. Based on this observation, we have reason to believe that ğ¦ğğ ğ¦ğğ \mathbf{meg} weakens the influence of potential noise, while ğ¥ğ ğ¥ğ \mathbf{lg} introduces new noise. Therefore, we can infer that while the mean parameters are steadily biased towards the personalized model, the introduction of new noise finds a path that is more likely to escape from local optima or saddle points, based on implicit regularizationÂ [61, 58, 57].

references:
Recently, personalized FL (PFL) is proposed to mitigate the aforementioned negative impact of heterogeneous dataÂ [66].
To improve the straightforward solution mentioned above, Per-FedAvgÂ [20] is introduced to train a global model that is easier to fine-tune. Another paper on the similar topic, FedProxÂ [45], aims to resolve the issue of personalized models drifting too far from the global model during training with a dynamic regularizer in the objective during local training. This issue could occur especially in post-training fine-tuning methods without regularization (e.g., Per-FedAvgÂ [20]).
Moreover, pFedMeÂ [65], another regularization method modeling local problems using Moreau envelopes, replaces FedProxâ€™s personalized model aggregation method with an interpretable approach for aggregating local modelsÂ [45]. It also accommodates first-order Per-FedAvgÂ [20].

Global Test and Local Test: the global and personalized model, represented by G and P, are evaluated with global and local tests respectively. Global test means all the test data is used in the test. Local test means only the local data is used for the local test and the weight of the sum in local test is the ratio of the number of data. The results of average accuracy per client are shown in TableÂ 1. Each experiment is repeated 5 times. More details are in AppendixÂ C. For readability, we only give the error bar in the main TableÂ 1 and TableÂ 2, and keep one decimal except for the main TableÂ 1.

We test the hyper-parameter effect of Î·ğœ‚\eta and Î»ğœ†\lambda in our implementation pFedBreDns,mh. The details are in AppendixÂ C. From the results, we find that it will degrade the test accuracy if the values of Î»ğœ†\lambda or Î·ğœ‚\eta are too large or too small. The test accuracy of personalized model is more sensitive than the ones of global model. The test accuracy of personalized model is more sensitive to Î·ğœ‚\eta than to Î»ğœ†\lambda. Note that the hyper-parameters are roughly tuned, which shows the insensitivity of ğ¦ğ¡ğ¦ğ¡\mathbf{mh}, and better tuning could improve the performance in the TableÂ 1.

From easy to difficult task: from the difference between the statistics of Avg and H.Avg in TableÂ 1, it can be observed that meta-step methods perform most consistently, with all other methods dropping at least 10%. This is due to the simple and effective local loss design of MAML, with its learning-to-learning design philosophy that enables the method to be more stable in complex situationsÂ [19, 20].

Absence of BNN on hard tasks: complex BNN is not in TableÂ 1, such as LSTM in pFedBayes, because it is difficult to conduct comparative experiments by fixing elements, e.g., inferential models, tricks and optimization methods. In pFedBayes, training often crashes on hard tasks and large datasets, as mentioned inÂ [77]. Our one-step-further research shows that it may be caused by the reparameterization tricks and vanilla Gaussian sampling. If we add tricks on it, the implementation will be very different from the original pFedBayes, and it is beyond this analysis.

We conduct ablation experiments by dropping the gradient of the Bregman-Moreau envelope, the local loss function, or both, from the personalized strategy ğ¦ğ¡ğ¦ğ¡\mathbf{mh} as shown in TableÂ 2.
The relationship among the three strategies mentioned in Eq.Â (14) is that ğ¦ğ¡ğ¦ğ¡\mathbf{mh} consists of ğ¥ğ ğ¥ğ \mathbf{lg} and ğ¦ğğ ğ¦ğğ \mathbf{meg}. Moreover, pFedMe can be regarded in our framework as the one which takes the spherical Gaussian as prior and uses vanilla prior selection strategy Î¼i=Isubscriptğœ‡ğ‘–ğ¼\mu_{i}=I without personalization. Thus, pFedMe and the three implementations of pFedBreD are compared.
The results reveal the instability of our implementation ğ¥ğ ğ¥ğ \mathbf{lg} and the introduction of ğ¦ğğ ğ¦ğğ \mathbf{meg} on difficult tasks is about the same as not introducing it. However, introducing both ğ¥ğ ğ¥ğ \mathbf{lg} and ğ¦ğğ ğ¦ğğ \mathbf{meg} (i.e., ğ¦ğ¡ğ¦ğ¡\mathbf{mh}) together shows remarkable performance. This indicates that ğ¥ğ ğ¥ğ \mathbf{lg} and ğ¦ğğ ğ¦ğğ \mathbf{meg} complement each other.
To explain these results, by observing the error bars, in most of the settings, ğ¦ğğ ğ¦ğğ \mathbf{meg} is significantly more stable compared to methods that do not use personalized priors, while ğ¥ğ ğ¥ğ \mathbf{lg} is relatively less stable. Based on this observation, we have reason to believe that ğ¦ğğ ğ¦ğğ \mathbf{meg} weakens the influence of potential noise, while ğ¥ğ ğ¥ğ \mathbf{lg} introduces new noise. Therefore, we can infer that while the mean parameters are steadily biased towards the personalized model, the introduction of new noise finds a path that is more likely to escape from local optima or saddle points, based on implicit regularizationÂ [61, 58, 57].

We analyze the impact of aggregation noise and data heterogeneityÂ [29] on our method, mainly ğ¦ğ¡ğ¦ğ¡\mathbf{mh}, by controlling variables. Results are in TableÂ 4 and TableÂ 4. (Details are in AppendixÂ C.8.)
We test the performance of global model on different aggregation ratios, where all hyper-parameters except for the aggregation ratios are fixed. Meanwhile, we test the performance of both global and the personalized model on different data heterogeneity settings, where full aggregation (sample client equals total number of clients, S=Nğ‘†ğ‘S=N) and one-step local update (local epoch R=1ğ‘…1R=1) are employed to get rid of the effects of aggregation noise and client drift.
The experiments demonstrate the instability of the global model in ğ¦ğ¡ğ¦ğ¡\mathbf{mh} at small aggregation ratios, which most of the other PFL methods have, by comparing their performances on different aggregation numbers. Comparing to the baselines, the experiments also demonstrate the relative robustness of our method to extreme data heterogeneity.
The main notations in this paper are shown in TableÂ 5.

Since the general process of our implementations, FedAMP and pFedMe are the same as shown in pFedBreD framework, these methods share the same complexity of memory/calculation, Oâ€‹(N)/Oâ€‹(Nâ€‹Tâ€‹Râ€‹K)ğ‘‚ğ‘ğ‘‚ğ‘ğ‘‡ğ‘…ğ¾O(N)/O(NTRK) as shown in TableÂ 6.
The complexities of both FedAvg and Per-FedAvg are Oâ€‹(N)/Oâ€‹(Nâ€‹Tâ€‹R)ğ‘‚ğ‘ğ‘‚ğ‘ğ‘‡ğ‘…O(N)/O(NTR) since the original methods of them do not need a approximate proximal mapping solution, and therefore are free on Kğ¾K, the number of iterations to calculate the solution.
The complexity of FedEM is Oâ€‹(Nâ€‹M)/Oâ€‹(Nâ€‹Tâ€‹Râ€‹M)ğ‘‚ğ‘ğ‘€ğ‘‚ğ‘ğ‘‡ğ‘…ğ‘€O(NM)/O(NTRM), where Mğ‘€M is the components of the distributions we assume, due to the calculation of Mğ‘€M components in each global epoch.

In addition, PFLâ€™s robustness is another essential aspect to consider. Real-world environments are often unpredictable and can interfere with the algorithmâ€™s performance, leading to erroneous results. Therefore, it is necessary to ensure that the algorithm is sufficiently robust before deploying it.

TableÂ 7 shows parts of the relationship between specific gğ‘”g and related member in exponential family. SeeÂ [6] for more about the relationships between gğ‘”g that derives Bregman divergence ğ’Ÿgsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘”\mathcal{D}_{g} and related derived divergence (e.g., â‹…Î£âˆ’1â‹…\cdot\Sigma^{-1}\cdot & Mahalanobis distance, âˆ‘â‹…â‹…logâ‹…\sum_{\cdot}\cdot\log\cdot & KL divergence / generalized I-divergence and etc.).

Based on the facts, the results in TableÂ 1 shows the instability of our personalized models. Here we propose a variant of ğ¦ğ¡ğ¦ğ¡\mathbf{mh}, shown in Eq.Â (24), trying to improve the robustness of personalized model on the original ğ¦ğ¡ğ¦ğ¡\mathbf{mh}, which use Î¦iâ†fi+Fiâ†subscriptÎ¦ğ‘–subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–subscriptğ¹ğ‘–\Phi_{i}\leftarrow f_{i}+F_{i}.

The experimental settings in SectionÂ 6.1 of the main paper have been utilized, with the exception of the client count for aggregation at the culmination of each global epoch. To ensure clarity, we present TableÂ 4 without well-tuning hyper-parameters (which are random selected in a narrow range with Gaussian variance of 0.01). Notably, supplementary experiments have been repeated 5 times to enhance the robustness of our analysis.

The results of experiments about different Non-IID settings are shown in TableÂ 4. The FMNIST in these experiments are equal number of total local data with different local data distribution the distribution are shown in FigureÂ 10. All experiments employ full aggregation of 40 clients and only 1 local epoch to get rid of the effects from aggregation noise and client drift caused by multiple local update.
The additional experiments with more baselines are shown in TableÂ 8 with the same settings mentioned in the TableÂ 1.

A1.T6.caption: Table 6: Complexity Comparison
references:
Since the general process of our implementations, FedAMP and pFedMe are the same as shown in pFedBreD framework, these methods share the same complexity of memory/calculation, Oâ€‹(N)/Oâ€‹(Nâ€‹Tâ€‹Râ€‹K)ğ‘‚ğ‘ğ‘‚ğ‘ğ‘‡ğ‘…ğ¾O(N)/O(NTRK) as shown in TableÂ 6.
The complexities of both FedAvg and Per-FedAvg are Oâ€‹(N)/Oâ€‹(Nâ€‹Tâ€‹R)ğ‘‚ğ‘ğ‘‚ğ‘ğ‘‡ğ‘…O(N)/O(NTR) since the original methods of them do not need a approximate proximal mapping solution, and therefore are free on Kğ¾K, the number of iterations to calculate the solution.
The complexity of FedEM is Oâ€‹(Nâ€‹M)/Oâ€‹(Nâ€‹Tâ€‹Râ€‹M)ğ‘‚ğ‘ğ‘€ğ‘‚ğ‘ğ‘‡ğ‘…ğ‘€O(NM)/O(NTRM), where Mğ‘€M is the components of the distributions we assume, due to the calculation of Mğ‘€M components in each global epoch.
